meanings.definition: To abandon or leave someone or something entirely.
meanings.sent1: She decided to forsake her old house and move to a new one.
meanings.sent2: He promised to never forsake his loyal dog.
meanings.sent3: The lost puppy looked at her with big eyes, as if to say, 'Please don't forsake me!'
meanings.sent4: The sailor had to forsake his sinking ship to save his own life.
meanings.sent5: The decision to forsake her toxic relationship brought her peace.

meanings.definition: To renounce or give up a belief or principle.
meanings.sent1: He had to forsake his dream of becoming a pilot due to his fear of heights.
meanings.sent2: She refused to forsake her values even under pressure.
meanings.sent3: The comedian joked, 'I had to forsake my diet when faced with a table full of desserts!'
meanings.sent4: In the face of adversity, he had to forsake his doubts and believe in himself.
meanings.sent5: The decision to forsake his old ways led to a new beginning.

meanings.definition: To fail to fulfill or carry out a duty or responsibility.
meanings.sent1: He would never forsake his promise to help his friend in need.
meanings.sent2: The company cannot forsake its commitment to customer satisfaction.
meanings.sent3: The forgetful professor would often forsake grading papers on time.
meanings.sent4: The knight could not forsake his duty to protect the kingdom.
meanings.sent5: The firefighter refused to forsake his duty to save lives, even in the face of danger.
